entities.text:
[it] remains unclear whether [LLMs] mathematical reasoning capabilities have genuinely advanced, raising questions about the reliability of the reported metrics... we conduct a large- scale study on several state-of-the-art open and closed models…
Our findings reveal that LLMs exhibit noticeable variance when responding to different instantiations of the same question. Specifically, the performance of all models declines when only the numerical values in the question are altered.. Furthermore, we investigate the fragility of mathematical reasoning in these models and demonstrate that their performance significantly deteriorates as the number of clauses in a question increases. We hypothesize that this decline is due to the fact that current LLMs are not capable of genuine logical reasoning; instead, they attempt to replicate the reasoning steps observed in their training data. When we add a single clause that appears relevant to the question, we observe significant performance drops…
arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05229

entities.text:
Apple Researchers Introduce GSM-Symbolic: A Novel Machine Learning Benchmark with Multiple Variants Designed to Provide Deeper Insights into the Mathematical Reasoning Abilities of LLMs

Researchers from Apple conducted a large-scale study to evaluate the reasoning capabilities of state-of-the-art LLMs using a new benchmark called GSM-Symbolic. This benchmark generates diverse mathematical questions through symbolic templates, allowing for more reliable and controllable evaluations. Their findings show that LLM performance declines significantly when numerical values or question complexity increases. Additionally, adding irrelevant but seemingly related information leads to a performance drop of up to 65%, indicating that LLMs rely on pattern matching rather than formal reasoning. The study highlights the need for improved evaluation methods and further research into LLM reasoning abilities.

The GSM8K dataset consists of over 8000 grade-school-level math questions and answers commonly used for evaluating LLMs. However, risks like data contamination and performance variance with minor question changes have arisen due to its popularity. To address this, GSM-Symbolic was developed, generating diverse problem instances using symbolic templates. This approach enables a more robust evaluation of LLMs, offering better control over question difficulty and testing the models’ capabilities across multiple variations. The benchmark evaluates over 20 open and closed models using 5000 samples from 100 templates, revealing insights into LLMs’ mathematical reasoning abilities and limitations....

Read the full article:
marktechpost.com/2024/10/13/app…
Paper:
arxiv.org/abs/2410.05229

entities.text:
大模型还没有真的学会推理。

苹果的研究者发表的这篇论文(
arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05229

)证明大模型的推理能力很不稳定，因此还不是真的“会推理”。

其中GSM-Symbolic测试为GSM8K的变体，通过符号模板可以生成一组不同的问题。发现仅更改问题中的物品名称或数值时，所有模型的性能都会下降。越小的模型下降幅度越大。

GSM-NoOp测试为添加看起来与问题有关但实际上对结果没影响的子句时，所有最先进的模型的性能都显著下降。越小的模型下降幅度越大，下降最小的o1-preview也有将近20%。

附图1: 更改问题中的物品名称或数值时各模型性能下降情况
附图2: GSM-NoOp的一个示例
附图3: 添加看似有关其实没有的子句时各模型性能下降情况

entities.text:
⚡️🚀המאמר היומי של מייק -12.10.24: ⚡️🚀

GSM-Symbolic: Understanding the Limitations of Mathematical Reasoning in Large Language Models

🔥האם מודלי שפה גדולים מסוגלים לעשות ריזונינג? השאלה הזו מעסיקה חוקרים רבים לאור יכולות די מרשימות שמודלי שפה מפגינים בפתרון שאלות לא פשוטות (אבל רק בתנאים מסוימים 🙂). המאמר בוחן את יכולות החשיבה המתמטית(שזה תת-יכולת של ריזונינג כללי) של LLMs ומציג את GSM-Symbolic, בנצ'מרק חדש לבחינת יכולות אלו שהם פיתחו.

🔥החוקרים מצאו שביצועי LLMs(נבחן מגוון רחב של מודלים: Gemma, Phi, Mistral, Llama3, GPT-4 ו-o1) משתנים באופן משמעותי כאשר משנים מעט את השאלות המתמטיות, מה שמעלה ספקות לגבי אמינות המדדים הקיימים. הביצועים של רוב המודלים יורדים כאשר עוברים מ-GSM8K המקורי ל-GSM-Symbolic, מה שמרמז על אפשרות של זיהום דאטה (contamination) במהלך האימון (כתבתי על זה לא מעט).

🔥בנוסף המודלים מראים רגישות גבוהה יותר לשינויים במספרים מאשר לשינויים בשמות עצם, מה שמעיד על חוסר יציבות ביכולות החשיבה שלהם. ככל שמספר המשפטים בשאלה עולה, הביצועים יורדים והשונות בביצועים עולה, מה שמצביע על קושי בטיפול בשאלות מורכבות יותר.

🔥החוקרים יצרו בנצ'מארק GSM-NoOp, שבו נוספו משפטים לא רלוונטיים לשאלות, וגילו ירידה דרמטית בביצועים של כל המודלים. אפילו כאשר ניתנו למודלים דוגמאות של אותה שאלה או שאלות דומות, הם התקשו להתגבר על האתגרים של GSM-NoOp.

🔥המחקר מצא שאימון נוסף על משימות קלות יותר וגם הגדלת כמות דאטה לאימון לא שיפרו את הביצועים במשימות מורכבות יותר.
קצת מנחם שלפחות מודלים חדשים יותר, כמו o1-preview ו-o1-mini, הראו ביצועים חזקים יותר, אך עדיין סבלו מהמגבלות שזוהו במחקר

🔥הממצאים מעלים ספקות לגבי היכולת האמיתית של LLMs לבצע חשיבה מתמטית פורמלית. נראה כי המודלים מסתמכים יותר על התאמת תבניות מאשר על חשיבה לוגית אמיתית. המחקר מדגיש את הצורך בשיטות הערכה אמינות יותר ובמחקר נוסף על יכולות החשיבה של מודלי שפה גדולים.

To truly understand advancements in the capabilities of AI and avoid premature concerns over stagnation, we need to focus on developing more robust, reliable measures of progress.

cs․LG | cs․AI, 07 Oct 2024

🆕GSM-Symbolic: Understanding the Limitations of Mathematical Reasoning in Large Language Models

Iman Mirzadeh, Keivan Alizadeh, Hooman Shahrokhi, Oncel Tuzel, Samy Bengio,...

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: Recent advancements in Large Language Models (LLMs) have sparked interest in their formal reasoning capabilities, particularly in mathematics.  The GSM8K benchmark is widely used to assess the mathematical reasoning of models on grade-school-level questions.  While the performance of LLMs on GSM8K has significantly improved in recent years, it remains unclear whether their mathematical reasoning capabilities have genuinely advanced, raising questions about the reliability of the reported metrics.  To address these concerns, we conduct a large-scale study on several SOTA open and closed models.  To overcome the limitations of existing evaluations, we introduce GSM-Symbolic, an improved benchmark created from symbolic templates that allow for the generation of a diverse set of questions.  GSM-Symbolic enables more controllable evaluations, providing key insights and more reliable metrics for measuring the reasoning capabilities of models.Our findings reveal that LLMs exhibit noticeabl...

entities.text: Apple Reveals Critical Flaws in AI's Logical Reasoning
arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05229

"GSM-Symbolic: Understanding the Limitations of Mathematical Reasoning in Large Language Models"

Chapter 5 Conclusion

"In this work, we have investigated the reasoning capabilities of large language models (LLMs) and the limitations of current evaluations on GSM8K. We introduced GSM-Symbolic, a novel benchmark with multiple variants designed to provide deeper insights into the mathematical reasoning abilities of
LLMs. Our extensive study reveals significant performance variability across different instantiations of the same question, challenging the reliability of current GSM8K results that rely on single-point accuracy metrics. We found that while LLMs exhibit some robustness to changes in proper names,
they are more sensitive to variations in numerical values. We have also observed the performance of LLMs deteriorating as question complexity increases.

The introduction of GSM-NoOp exposes a critical flaw in LLMs’ ability to genuinely understand mathematical concepts and discern relevant information for problem-solving. Adding seemingly relevant but ultimately inconsequential information to the logical reasoning of the problem led to substantial performance drops of up to 65% across all state-of-the-art models. Importantly, we demonstrate that LLMs struggle even when provided with multiple examples of the same question or examples containing similar irrelevant information. This suggests deeper issues in their reasoning
processes that cannot be easily mitigated through few-shot learning or fine-tuning.

Ultimately, our work underscores significant limitations in the ability of LLMs to perform genuine mathematical reasoning. The high variance in LLM performance on different versions of the same question, their substantial drop in performance with a minor increase in difficulty, and their sensitivity
to inconsequential information indicate that their reasoning is fragile. It may resemble sophisticated pattern matching more than true logical reasoning. We remind the reader that both GSM8K and GSM-Symbolic include relatively simple grade-school math questions, requiring only basic arithmetic
operations at each step. Hence, the current limitations of these models are likely to be more pronounced in more challenging mathematical benchmarks.

We believe further research is essential to develop AI models capable of formal reasoning, moving beyond pattern recognition to achieve more robust and generalizable problem-solving skills. This remains a critical challenge for the field as we strive to create systems with human-like cognitive
abilities or general intelligence."

entities.text: 3/ Introducing GSM-Symbolic—our new tool to test the limits of LLMs in mathematical reasoning. We create symbolic templates from the
#GSM8K

test set, enabling the generation of numerous instances and the design of controllable experiments.  We generate 50 unique GSM-Symbolic sets, essentially like GSM8K examples but with different values and names. How do models handle these distinct sets?

user.name: Mehrdad Farajtabar
user.description: Research Scientist at @Apple, prev @DeepMind, prev @GeorgiaTech

entities.text: #Result

1: Current accuracies on GSM8K are not reliable! We observe LARGE performance variation: Llama 8B scores anywhere between 70% to 80%, Phi-3 scores between 75% and 90%, and so on.  For most models, the average performance on GSM-Symbolic is lower than on GSM8K (indicated by the dashed line).

user.name: Mehrdad Farajtabar
user.description: Research Scientist at @Apple, prev @DeepMind, prev @GeorgiaTech

entities.text: #Result

2: The fragility of supposed LLM reasoning. LLMs remain sensitive to changes in proper names (e.g., people, foods, objects), and even more so when numbers are altered. Would a grade-school student's math test score vary by ~10% if we only changed the names?

user.name: Mehrdad Farajtabar
user.description: Research Scientist at @Apple, prev @DeepMind, prev @GeorgiaTech

entities.text: 6/ What if we adjust question difficulty? We introduce 3 new variants of GSM-Symbolic to study model behavior: removing one clause (GSM-M1), adding one clause (GSM-P1), or adding two clauses (GSM-P2).

user.name: Mehrdad Farajtabar
user.description: Research Scientist at @Apple, prev @DeepMind, prev @GeorgiaTech

entities.text: #Result
3: As questions increase in difficulty (M1 → Symbolic → P1 → P2), not only does performance drop, but variance also rises, making models increasingly unreliable.

entities.text:
Large Language Models don't reason. Says Apple Paper. 🤔

Reveals LLMs lack robust mathematical reasoning, relying on pattern matching rather than genuine conceptual understanding.

Now generally till now, LLMs have shown impressive performance on grade-school math tasks like GSM8K. But it's unclear if they truly have mathematical reasoning abilities or if reported metrics are reliable.

**Solution in this Paper** 🔬:

• Introduces GSM-Symbolic benchmark with templates to generate diverse question variants
• Allows evaluating LLM performance as a distribution across different instantiations
• Examines impact of changing names vs numbers, increasing difficulty, adding irrelevant info

**Key Insights from this Paper** 💡:

• LLMs show high variance in performance across different variants of same question
• More sensitive to changes in numbers than names
• Performance degrades and variance increases with more complex questions
• Adding irrelevant but plausible info causes major drops in accuracy (up to 65%)
• Results suggest LLMs lack true mathematical reasoning, rely on pattern matching

**Results** 📊:

• Performance on GSM-Symbolic lower than GSM8K for most models (e.g. 87% vs 79.1% for Gemma2-9b)
• Changing only numbers drops performance more than changing only names
• Accuracy decreases as question difficulty increases (e.g. 84.4% → 79.1% → 68.1% → 41.8% for Gemma2-9b)
• GSM-NoOp dataset with irrelevant info causes 20-65% accuracy drops across all models

entities.text:
I wonder how much of the improvement in performance is because of goodhart's law

“When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure”

I.e. is better performance on benchmark tests translatable to real world performance?

A team at Apple recently published a really interesting paper where they tested LLM performance with GSM (a standard benchmark test used to evaluate LLM mathematical reasoning ability) 

But they modified the stem of the questions with extra unnecessary information to distract the LLMs

It led to much lower accuracy even for OpenAI’s o1 model

This seems especially relevant for real world cases which are full of extra information that is not necessary to reach an accurate conclusion

but often lead to inaccuracies/distractions in LLM outputs

user.name: Adam Bataineh MD
user.description: founder @ https://t.co/JJynFzHHz2 & @Span_health (acquired by Eight Sleep). Evidence-based longevity. oncology specialist registrar. MD, MSc, PGCert, MRCP

entities.text:
In this specific test, it should translate to real world performance.

This specific test is designed to measure a model’s ability to perform tasks it’s not specifically trained on. It does have a training set, but that set is there for the models to learn the format of the questions, not to be able to understand the answers.

The reason the models are performing so well on these tests is twofold: general improvement in performance of the models themselves, and using a new technique called time scale computing, which is giving the models a lot more time to answer the question.

This is why the cost per task of the large model is around $1000, because it’s using so much compute in the process.

However, it is now on par with a stem grad, although at 100x the cost.

user.name: Paul 'Ed' Bishop
user.description: Helping Construction Service Businesses Owners Embrace AI to get back 25% of their time to invest back in their business.

entities.text:
Has mathematical reasoning in LLMs really advanced?

This study tests several SoTA models on a benchmark created with symbolic templates that enable diverse mathematical problems.

They find that LLMs exhibit variance when responding to variations of the same questions.

The performance of all the models declines by adjusting the numerical values in the question.

Another interesting finding is that as questions are made more challenging (e.g., increasing the number of clauses) the performance significantly deteriorates.

The authors hypothesize that the observed decline in performance is due to a lack of logical reasoning in current LLMs.

The study highlights the importance of model reliability and robustness and why it's important to continuously evaluate LLM systems after being deployed. This is not just for math-related problems, this also happened for use cases involving analysis, research, Q&A, and retrieval. We have seen that adjustments in prompts that have to deal with knowledge, numbers, retrieval, or structure can throw off the model so there is a need to trace LLMs and monitor them in production.

entities.text: Yes!  As I've stated numerous times, AI is utterly incapable of logic and reason.  Not only was the 2024 Nobel Prize in Physics not awarded to advancements in physics, but AI isn't intelligent.  AI is incapable of reason, creativity, innovation, and exalted idealism. It has been said that God created man in His own image, but these days many AI bros are trying to create AI in their own image and call that God, or at least a "Ph.D. in your pocket lol bro."  But AI can only ever be as ethical as the foundations it was built upon--the art, science, poetry and beautiful human creativity it was trained on.  Plato saw beauty in Justice, but their AI sees no beauty.  Were Natural Rights, Artists' Rights, Copyright, and Human Rights respected during the training? If not, the AI is not, and cannot be ethical--as Hamlet noted--"It is not, and it cannot, come to good."  And all for what? OpenAI's o1 strawberry pop-tart/stochastic parrot is incapable of simple logic and reason, exalted art, truth, and beauty.  To demonstrate this, give it the geometric definitions in Book 1 of Euclid's Elements, and then ask it to complete the rest of Euclid's Elements using simple logic and reason oft employed by junior high schoolers.  It won't be able to.  So it is that AI algorithms are incapable of meaningful scientific research, useful invention, or creative art. There will be no AGI from LLMS nor any other "AI" fantasy.  Getting AGI from an LLM is like trying to turn a Model X Tesla into the Millenium Falcon by buiding it bigger.  All of scientific cultural advancement--all science and technology--is centered upon humans answering questions that nobody knew the answer to, and even more importantly, it is premised upon humans asking questions nobody has asked before.  LLMs cannot do any of this.   Einstein reminds us that "imagination is more important than knowledge," and too, he stated, "Never lose a holy curiosity."  AI has no curiosity.  AI LLMS are utterly incapable of AGI, logic, reason, and creative logos.  This is easily demonstrated. No AI/LLM could produce Euclid's Elements from the simple definitions give in Book I.  AI LLMs are mere autocomplete, and thus have very little (perhaps nothing) to do with human intelligence. AI is incapable of creating anything new or beautiful beyond that which it ingested/copied/stole.  One of the problems with LLM/"AI" development is that all too often the CEOs are recreating it in their own image--folks who never created art nor culture nor ingested nor trained their souls on the data found in Beethoven's, Van Gogh's, Shakespeare's, and Einstein's works.  For instance, while Sam Altman's AI may well be able to duplicate/parrot the String Theory hoax, it, like Altman, will utterly fail to advance physics, or any other noble field, in any manner.   GPT-5 will be far, far, far inferior to all the artists and physicists it copied, ingested, and stole from.  Let us quickly prove this.  Train AI on all music known to humanity before Beethoven. Then ask it to create Beethoven's symphonies, or just the third or ninth. Train AI on all literature known to humanity before Shakespeare, and then ask it to write Hamlet. Train AI on all science known to humanity before relativity, and then ask it to create special and general relativity. Train AI on all math and physics known before Newton, and then ask it to write Principia. Train AI on all philosophy known before Plato, and then ask it to write Socrates' Apology. Train AI on all music known before the Beatles, and then ask it to create the White Album. Train AI on all the art created before Michelangelo, and then ask it to create the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel. Train AI on all the techonology created before Steve Jobs, and then ask it to create Apple. Train AI on all the music that existed before the blues, and then ask it to describe love and heartbreak in music, or just to recognize it. Train AI on all art known before Van Gogh, and then ask it to paint starry nights, sunflowers, and self portraits such as those that are worth hundreds of millions of dollars today.  Train AI on all epic poetry known to humanity before Homer, and then ask it to write Homer's Iliad and Odyssey. So it is that AI is most often championed by those who have little appreciation for or understanding of Beethoven, Shakespeare, Einstein, Newton, Plato, The Beatles, Van Gogh, Homer, Michelangelo, Steve Jobs, music, literature, science, math, philosophy, art, technology, love, and epic poetry. Perhaps they even detest these exalted entities on some level.

entities.text:
This is pretty 🤯 discovery.

LLMs are becoming more brain like as they advance, researchers discover.

Researchers at Columbia University and Feinstein Institutes for Medical  Research Northwell Health recently carried out a study investigating the  similarities between LLM representations on neural responses. Their  findings, published in Nature Machine Intelligence, suggest that as LLMs become more advanced, they do not only perform better, but they also become more brain like.

"First, we found that as LLMs get more powerful (for example, as they  get better at answering questions like ChatGPT), their embeddings  become more similar to the brain's neural responses to language," said  Mischler.

"More  surprisingly, as LLM performance increases, their alignment with the  brain's hierarchy also increases. This means that the amount and type of  information extracted over successive brain regions during language  processing aligns better with the information extracted by successive  layers of the highest-performing LLMs than it does with low-performing  LLMs."

The results gathered by this team of researchers suggest that the  best performing LLMs mirror brain responses associated with language  processing more closely. Moreover, their better performance appears to  be due to the greater efficiency of their earlier layers.

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: 最近の大規模言語モデル（LLM）の進歩は、特に数学において、その形式的推論能力への関心を呼んでいる。GSM8Kベンチマークは、小学生レベルの問題に対するモデルの数学的推論を評価するために広く使用されている。GSM8KにおけるLLMの成績は近年著しく向上しているが、彼らの数学的推論能力が本当に進歩したのかどうかは依然として不明であり、報告されているメトリクスの信頼性については疑問が残る。これらの懸念に対処するため、我々はいくつかのSOTAオープンモデルとクローズドモデルについて大規模な研究を行った。既存の評価の限界を克服するために、多様な問題セットを生成できる記号テンプレートから作成された改良型ベンチマークであるGSM-Symbolicを紹介する。GSM-Symbolicは、より制御可能な評価を可能にし、モデルの推論能力を測定するための重要な洞察と、より信頼性の高い測定基準を提供します。私たちの発見は、LLMが同じ質問の異なるインスタンスに応答する際に顕著なばらつきを示すことを明らかにしました。具体的には、GSM-Symbolicベンチマークでは、問題の数値だけを変更すると、すべてのモデルの性能が低下する。さらに、これらのモデルにおける数学的...

entities.text: Some of you may think that the AGI monster is just around the corner. I am here to help you understand the limitations of current AI models.

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text:
I had so many friends who, even though they are smart people, they were afraid that the AI revolution will be humanity's end. They signed petitions to delay the training of new models, they were always talking about the doom coming to get us.

They're fine now. (I put the bunny away)

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text:
To be honest, I believe humanity will transcend (at some point in the future) and it will merge with AIs. But let's leave the crazy talk for another time.

I want to present some research related to LLM reasoning.

I will go through the most important points of the research, its conclusion and will add my own thoughts to it.

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text: The hypothesis is that the current state of the art (SotA) LLMs can't exactly reason, they act like they understand the problems and can work out the steps to solve them because they've seen the same problems during the training process.

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text: To find out if that's the case, the researchers started from a very popular problem set, known as GSM8K, containing ~8k high quality grade school math word problems, created by

entities.name: OpenAI
entities.text: @openai
You can find the whole dataset here.
huggingface.co/datasets/opena…

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text:
Starting from this dataset, they created a "symbolic" version of it, where the key elements would be replaced by others from a limited list. For example they changed the names of the characters, the numbers of items they interact with. 

To the left you can see the original problem, while right side you have the symbolic version of that same problem. This allows them to mutate the original problem and test whether there is a difference between solving the original problem versus a mutated version of it.

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text:
Since GSM8K is extremely popular, there is a chance that this problem set has been used in the training of some models.

If we're considering this possibility, it's interesting to note that other older papers, have seen much lower success rate with previous SotA models in 2021.

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text:
Below you can see GPT3 having a maximum of 35% success rate. 

While recently we see 95% maximum success rate.

Once could argue that current models are much larger, and training techniques have evolved. But there's also the possibility that the GSM8K data set has been used to train the current models.

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text:
The main results they got when checking SotA models against the GSM-Symbolic dataset can be seen below. 

The vertical dashed line is the success rate against GSM8K (unaltered dataset), while the blue line represents the success distribution against GSM-Symbolic.

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text:
We can see how this varies when an 8-shot Chain-of-Thought test is performed across multiple problems, with different SotA models.

All models have less success against the mutated dataset. Some more than others. 
GPT-4o seems to be the best at solving (remember that OpenAI created this dataset orginally)

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text: The researchers wanted to understand what causes the worst performance drop when mutating datasets. Remember they created a symbolic version, having the possibility to replace names (humans and items) and numbers.

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text:
Thus, they ran tests with:
- only numbers changed
- only names changed
- both changed

And observed that typically changing both creates a higher performance drop, while changing names creates the least performance drop.

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text: Only changing the names does not change the result of the problem. But changing numbers forces the LLM to come up with the (new) correct result.

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text:
And they went even further. They wanted to see if changing the difficulty of the problem, affects the success rate and how.

Thus they created 3 more types of problems based on the original one.

1. GSM-M1 - removed a clause from the original problem, making the problem simpler.
2. GSM-P1 - added one additional clause
3. GSM-P2 - added two additional clauses

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text: The impact of more complex problems reduced the accuracy of the models, while also increasing the variance.

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text: To make things even more interesting, they created another set GSM-NoOp (no operation), which adds a clause which is irrelevant to the problem and does not affect the solution in any way.

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text: If LLMs can actually reason, we should see a minimal variance in performance. However, the GSM-NoOp was able to reduce accuracy by 17% up to 65%.

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text: Surprisingly, some models (Gemma2b, Mistral-7b-v0.1) perform much better with the GSM-NoOp dataset compared even with the original one.

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text:
In conclusion, it seems that:

1. LLMs' reasoning abilities are fragile : Their performance varies significantly across different question instantiations, making them unreliable.

2. Genuine mathematical understanding is lacking : LLMs struggle with true logical reasoning and can be misled by seemingly relevant but inconsequential information.

3. Further research is essential for robust problem-solving : To develop AI models capable of formal reasoning, we need to move beyond pattern recognition and create systems with more generalizable problem-solving skills.

user.name: Daniel Luca 🦄
user.description: Perpetual Progress. Tech Partner @edenblockvc | Dev, Security, Investor | ex @fiatdao, @ConsenSysAudits, @alethioethstats @consensys🦇🔊 | crypto since '17

entities.text:
While the researchers' findings are indeed fascinating, I'd like to offer a more optimistic interpretation. 

Instead of viewing LLMs as fragile or lacking genuine mathematical understanding, what if we see them as... incomplete, but still remarkable tools for pattern recognition and problem-solving?

Even with their limitations, modern LLMs have achieved unprecedented success in various tasks, from language translation to content generation. Perhaps the issue isn't that they can't reason or understand math, but rather that we're asking them to perform tasks that are too complex, too abstract, or too dependent on human context.

The findings of the research don't necessarily indicate a need to "go back to square one" with AI development. Rather, they suggest that we should emphasize the strengths of LLMs while acknowledging their limitations.

entities.text: It’s a garbage paper with garbage conclusions starting right from the abstract.

Breakdown of the paper:

The researchers wanted to understand the limitations of mathematical reasoning in large language models (LLMs). They used the GSM8K benchmark, which tests the mathematical reasoning abilities of models on grade-school-level questions.

The researchers found that LLMs exhibit significant performance variation across different instantiations of the same question, even when only proper names or numerical values are changed. They also observed that the performance of all models declines as the number of clauses in a question increases. Additionally, they introduced GSM-NoOp, which adds seemingly relevant but ultimately irrelevant information to the questions, and found that this led to substantial performance drops of up to 65% across all models.

full paper:
openread.academy/en/paper/readi…

entities.text:
The paper behind it:

This study explores the parallels between large language models (LLMs) and the human brain's language processing mechanisms. It investigates how the performance and architectural features of LLMs align with the hierarchical processing observed in the brain during speech comprehension.

The study found that higher-performing LLMs not only exhibited greater overall brain similarity, but they also achieved peak predictive accuracy in earlier layers compared to lower-performing models. Additionally, the researchers discovered that the hierarchical alignment between the LLMs and the brain's language processing pathway was strongly correlated with the models' performance on benchmark tasks.

user.name: John Ball
user.description: I'm an inventor: scientist and engineer. My passion is in modeling the brains of animals to make machines more useful - with language. We're getting there!

entities.text:
There are two key words commonly used to discuss progress in AI. One is 'intelligence.' Is intelligence a thing or just a catch word for anything humans do? 

The second is 'reasoning.' If human brains generate answers, is that reasoning? If we follow the same pattern we used last time, isn't that one of the tasks to emulate? 

The point is that 'reasoning' and 'intelligence' are spoken about as if they represent something we can mimic, when in fact they are vague concepts that can be argued about. Wouldn't a focus on skills that we see animals perform that are outside of our technologies be more useful in the short term than leaderboards in solving tasks that brute force computing can copy from huge numbers of examples? 

What's the best progress measurement?  Moravec's Paradox is the area that has seem little to no progress since the 1950s... Why not address the hard problems of AI rather than the comparatively easy ones?

entities.text:
The question of whether Large Language Models (LLMs) can truly reason or are merely sophisticated pattern matchers is a hot topic in AI research. In our latest preprint, we delve into this debate through an extensive study of both open-source models like Llama, Phi, Gemma, and Mistral, as well as leading closed models, including the recent OpenAI GPT-4o and o1-series.

Our findings reveal that while LLMs exhibit impressive capabilities in various tasks, their reasoning abilities often resemble advanced pattern matching rather than genuine logical reasoning¹². This distinction is crucial for understanding the limitations and potential applications of these models in real-world scenarios.

The paper's conclusion is half true.  The claim that they are sophisticated pattern matching is dependent on the training, not necessarily better data or more parameters. :x
They found what they were looking for, and thus claimed that it was so, without checking to see if you could shift the attention heads with curated data, to encourage the model not to only "pattern match".
We know with certainty that the training can shift from memorization to more being more general. However if you're not careful you'll end with attention heads trying to perform the goals you imparted on them. 
As Ilya stated; are they reciting remembered patterns or doing more complex generalization?
 Yes.      ...It depends. :x

entities.text:
I applaud the work done by the team, especially because current benchmarks are too vulnerable to memorization. GSM-Symbolic seems like a step in the right direction.

For one, it seems that model distillation might be less efficient than we previously thought.

As for o1-preview specifically, it would interesting if OAI allowed us to increase test time inference at the API level. I'm curious to see if the -17% drop would persist given a longer CoT.

Now, I don't see how the test results support the broad claims people are making. If LLMs couldn't reason at all we wouldn't be discussing the degree of the drops observed and how these models are vulnerable to misdirection. They would have failed the tests outright.

Some people are overstating the negative as much as the research labs are overstating their models' reasoning capabilities.

entities.text: As I've stated numerous times, AI is incapable of reason, creativity, innovation, and exalted idealism. Not only was the 2024 Nobel Prize in Physics not awarded to advancements in physics, but AI isn't intelligent. It has been said that God created man in His own image, but these days many AI bros are trying to create AI in their own image and call that God, or at least a "Ph.D. in your pocket lol bro."  But AI can only ever be as ethical as the foundations it was built upon--the art, science, poetry and beautiful human creativity it was trained on.  Plato saw beauty in Justice, but their AI sees no beauty.  Were Natural Rights, Artists' Rights, Copyright, and Human Rights respected during the training? If not, the AI is not, and cannot be ethical--as Hamlet noted--"It is not, and it cannot, come to good."  And all for what? OpenAI's o1 strawberry pop-tart/stochastic parrot is incapable of simple logic and reason, exalted art, truth, and beauty.  To demonstrate this, give it the geometric definitions in Book 1 of Euclid's Elements, and then ask it to complete the rest of Euclid's Elements using simple logic and reason oft employed by junior high schoolers.  It won't be able to.  So it is that AI algorithms are incapable of meaningful scientific research, useful invention, or creative art. There will be no AGI from LLMS nor any other "AI" fantasy.  Getting AGI from an LLM is like trying to turn a Model X Tesla into the Millenium Falcon by buiding it bigger.  All of scientific cultural advancement--all science and technology--is centered upon humans answering questions that nobody knew the answer to, and even more importantly, it is premised upon humans asking questions nobody has asked before.  LLMs cannot do any of this.   Einstein reminds us that "imagination is more important than knowledge," and too, he stated, "Never lose a holy curiosity."  AI has no curiosity.  AI LLMS are utterly incapable of AGI, logic, reason, and creative logos.  This is easily demonstrated. No AI/LLM could produce Euclid's Elements from the simple definitions give in Book I.  AI LLMs are mere autocomplete, and thus have very little (perhaps nothing) to do with human intelligence. AI is incapable of creating anything new or beautiful beyond that which it ingested/copied/stole.  One of the problems with LLM/"AI" development is that all too often the CEOs are recreating it in their own image--folks who never created art nor culture nor ingested nor trained their souls on the data found in Beethoven's, Van Gogh's, Shakespeare's, and Einstein's works.  For instance, while Sam Altman's AI may well be able to duplicate/parrot the String Theory hoax, it, like Altman, will utterly fail to advance physics, or any other noble field, in any manner.   GPT-5 will be far, far, far inferior to all the artists and physicists it copied, ingested, and stole from.  Let us quickly prove this.  Train AI on all music known to humanity before Beethoven. Then ask it to create Beethoven's symphonies, or just the third or ninth. Train AI on all literature known to humanity before Shakespeare, and then ask it to write Hamlet. Train AI on all science known to humanity before relativity, and then ask it to create special and general relativity. Train AI on all math and physics known before Newton, and then ask it to write Principia. Train AI on all philosophy known before Plato, and then ask it to write Socrates' Apology. Train AI on all music known before the Beatles, and then ask it to create the White Album. Train AI on all the art created before Michelangelo, and then ask it to create the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel. Train AI on all the techonology created before Steve Jobs, and then ask it to create Apple. Train AI on all the music that existed before the blues, and then ask it to describe love and heartbreak in music, or just to recognize it. Train AI on all art known before Van Gogh, and then ask it to paint starry nights, sunflowers, and self portraits such as those that are worth hundreds of millions of dollars today.  Train AI on all epic poetry known to humanity before Homer, and then ask it to write Homer's Iliad and Odyssey. So it is that AI is most often championed by those who have little appreciation for or understanding of Beethoven, Shakespeare, Einstein, Newton, Plato, The Beatles, Van Gogh, Homer, Michelangelo, Steve Jobs, music, literature, science, math, philosophy, art, technology, love, and epic poetry. Perhaps they even detest these exalted entities on some level.

entities.text:
1. Why does this section only contain results for models 9b and smaller? Other experiments in the paper include 4o and o1.

2. I don't know whether the ~10% variability was caused by the names, because I don't know the variability of the control group. The figure here includes the reported GSM8K score for Gemma2-9b, but that tells us nothing about its variability. What is the distribution of Gemma2-9b's GSM8K scores if you keep running it with a random seed and the same temperature it was set to for the test group?

3. Lots of research has been done on how student performance is affected by framing, including by using familiar people and objects. Some studies have found an effect and some haven't, seems like it probably varies a lot based on things like the difficulty of the problem and the age of the student. But it's definitely not out of the question to suggest that human performance might change based on what names used in the problem.

user.name: Christiaan de Leeuw
user.description: Bioloog | data analist

entities.text: We have seen from other papers that pattern matching and logical processes live in superposition within the network. With networks initially relying on pattern matching and slowly switching to logical processes over time - 'grokking'. What you are seeing is the probabilistic interference of these two modes. Adapted training methods that preferentially train these 'slower' more logical modes of learning are coming - and additionally larger nets seem to be less effected as their size increases. Additionally you will notice similar effects in the human mind, with logic crystalising out rather than being evident from the start. Your work seems to highlight the similarity to human minds rather than diminish it and in so doing bolsters the case that these machines are in fact a serious path to AGI - despite your intent.

entities.text: EMNLP 2024 Main: "A Peek into Token Bias: Large Language Models Are Not Yet Genuine Reasoners"
arxiv.org/abs/2406.11050

TD; DR: The generalization of reasoning capabilities still suffers from token bias. It is a probabilistic pattern matching rather than genuine reasoning.

🕑Tuesday 16:00 - 17:30
📍Riverfront Hall

We support the findings in🍎Apple's trending GSM-Symbolic paper, which has referenced our work to question the true reasoning abilities of LLMs. LLMs perform impressively on reasoning benchmarks 📊, but we wonder if the language model's performance on reasoning benchmarks is a mirage? 🤔

We'll be at EMNLP

entities.name: EMNLP 2025
entities.text: @emnlpmeeting
tomorrow at 4 PM in the poster session🌟 at Riverfront Hall, sharing our latest research with guidance from

entities.name: Dan Roth
entities.text: @DanRothNLP

entities.name: Camillo Jose Taylor
entities.text: @camillo_taylor

entities.name: Weijie Su
entities.text: @weijie444
from Penn

entities.name: Penn Engineering
entities.text: @PennEngineers

entities.name: The Wharton School
entities.text: @Wharton
and

entities.name: Tanwi Mallick
entities.text: @tanwimallick
from Argonne

entities.name: Argonne National Lab
entities.text: @argonne

🤖 We developed a hypothesis-testing framework that tests models on classic logic problems. We perform token perturbations, especially those tokens irrelevant to the underlying logic, and observe statistically significant results. We call this the token bias💡

For instance, the famous "Linda Problem" in psycholog👩‍⚕️ is usually answered correctly.  However, change it to the "Bob Problem"👨‍⚕️, the performance shifts. Similarly, we swap "horses🐎" for "bunnies🐰" in the "twenty-five horses problem" in graph theory. These changes don’t affect the underlying logic but highlight memorization🧠over genuine reasoning🤔

Come chat with us at the session!

entities.text:
이건 정말 🤯 새로운 발견이네요.

연구자들은 LLM이 발전함에 따라 뇌와 더욱 유사해지고 있다는 사실을 발견했습니다.

컬럼비아 대학교와 파인스타인 의학 연구소 노스웰 헬스의 연구원들은 최근 신경 반응에 대한 LLM 표현 간의 유사성을 조사하는 연구를 수행했습니다. Nature Machine Intelligence에 게재된 그들의 연구 결과에 따르면 LLM이 더 발전함에 따라 성능이 더 좋아질 뿐만 아니라 뇌와 더 비슷해진다고 합니다.

Mischler는 "첫째, LLM이 더 강력해질수록(예를 들어, ChatGPT와 같은 질문에 대답하는 데 능숙해질수록) 임베딩이 언어에 대한 뇌의 신경 반응과 더 유사해진다는 것을 발견했습니다."라고 말했습니다.

"더욱 놀랍게도 LLM 성과가 증가함에 따라 뇌의 계층 구조와의 일치도 증가합니다. 즉, 언어 처리 중에 연속적인 뇌 영역에서 추출된 정보의 양과 유형이 성과가 낮은 LLM보다 성과가 가장 높은 LLM의 연속적인 계층에서 추출된 정보와 더 잘 일치한다는 것을 의미합니다."

이 연구팀이 수집한 결과는 가장 성능이 좋은 LLM이 언어 처리와 관련된 뇌 반응을 더 밀접하게 반영한다는 것을 시사합니다. 게다가, 그들의 더 나은 성능은 이전 계층의 효율성이 더 높기 때문인 것으로 보입니다.

entities.text:
New research shows that LLMs are becoming more brain-like as they improve performance. 𝗜𝘁'𝘀 𝗵𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗲𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴. 𝗟𝗟𝗠𝘀 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗯𝗿𝗮𝗶𝗻𝘀. 🤣🤣 

The paper claims that higher-performing LLMs align with brain activity in language processing, showing similar hierarchical feature extraction patterns.[1] It even includes pictures of brains to strengthen its argument. 

I will ignore the issues in experimental design.[2] Instead, I want to consider the claims of convergence, which are justified by functional alignment. LLMs process language, as do humans; therefore, the authors assume all comparisons are warranted, and any overlap in "activity" reveals fundamental principles shared by artificial and biological systems. 

1.) I find this disingenuous. LLMs are not designed to be biologically plausible. LLMs are optimized for next-word prediction and do not simulate or replicate neuronal activity. The underlying substrates (neurons vs. tensors) and mechanisms (spiking activity vs. matrix multiplications) differ entirely. Comparing them post hoc is misleading. 

2.) This research is not used to predict aspects of LLM architecture or performance based on any alignment. Instead, the researchers merely observe overlap and use that to claim that LLMs are becoming brains. 

3.) The study uses brain similarity after observing alignment in prior work. Why should this metric be prioritized over others, especially when model design ignored biological plausibility?

4.) It is irrelevant. The success of LLMs demonstrates that performance does not require mimicking biological processes. Hence, using the brain as a post hoc benchmark ignores its irrelevance to model development. 

Aligning LLMs with the brain makes for a compelling narrative and feeds into the speculative discourse around artificial general intelligence, which thrives on ambiguous comparisons to human cognition. However, 𝗶𝗳 𝗟𝗟𝗠𝘀 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝗯𝗿𝗮𝗶𝗻𝘀, 𝘄𝗵𝘆 𝗮𝗿𝗲𝗻'𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝘆 𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝗯𝗿𝗮𝗶𝗻𝘀? 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝘀𝘄𝗲𝗿 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗟𝗟𝗠𝘀 𝗮𝗿𝗲𝗻'𝘁 𝗯𝗿𝗮𝗶𝗻𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘄𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻'𝘁 𝗱𝗲𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗻𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗯𝗲. 

Brains and LLMs solve fundamentally different problems under fundamentally different constraints, using radically different architectures. Even if someone accepts that LLMs are becoming "brain-like" (whatever that means), they are not brains or cognitively plausible. The claim that LLMs are "becoming more brain-like" is academic hype. Instead of framing AI progress in terms of alignment with biology, researchers should focus on developing AI on its terms, solving problems where it excels without misleading analogies to human cognition.

user.name: a13i
user.description: What dost thou seek?

entities.text: This "paper," published by research scientists

entities.name: Apple
entities.text: @Apple
with former @DeepMind employees among them, and re-tweeted by the elsewhere sharply skeptical

entities.name: Sabine Hossenfelder
entities.text: @skdh

, achieves one thing: 

1. Develops yet another arbitrary benchmark that LLMs are currently bad at 

That's it. It doesn't do anything else. So is that how they report their results? Of course not. 

They begin with the big question: Can LLMs truly reason?  One would be forgiven for thinking, with such a question asked in what is ostensibly a paper written by thinking adults trained in learned establishments, that the authors might go on to say what they mean by "truly reason." 

But one would be mistaken. 

Instead, they say nothing of the sort, and immediately begin defining their arbitrary system for tricking chatbots. 

They never touch the concept of "reason" again. Literally. The paper does not even contain a reference to a different paper that might tell us what they mean by "true logical reasoning," or "genuine mathematical reason," or any of the other nebulous ways it's referred to in the first couple of sentences. 

That is, until the conclusion, of course—where we are duly informed, after pages of painstaking bean countery, that what we've just witnessed is somehow an investigation of the "reasoning capabilities" of large language models. 

I'm sorry, but how does a paper demonstrate anything regarding a concept about which it contains no understanding, no mention, and indeed not even a definition? Are we to imagine that hidden somewhere in this chatbot-trap is the acid test of the self-referencing soul? 

Frankly, for all of my sardonic hostility, it's a neat new benchmark they've developed. But the packaging is so distasteful, so predictably banal and devoid of even the barest hint that any of its publishers have any desire whatsoever to probe the actual questions they're pretending to answer, that I can't enjoy it. 

Is this really what the industry's best and brightest are up to?

entities.text:
I applaud the authors for proposing a new benchmark that goes beyond GSM8K. But after reading this work, it seems that most of the identified issues are due to poor associative-recall performance and not reasoning per se.

For example, this work introduces GSM-NoOp in which a plausible relevant statement is introduced which is indeed irrelevant. And this seems to break the model's performance.

But GSM-NoOp is very similar to SQUAD-V2 benchmark, indicating that these models just don't have a good recall performance.

entities.text:
This is very interesting paper, but disagree with hypothesis that it shows that "current LLMs are not capable of genuine logical reasoning." 

There is a confounder here:

Many top LLMs are *chat models*. Chat is very different from math exams. Chats are messy, and to do a good job there you often need to guess at the intent of the user, and take advantage of any information provided in the prompt, even when it does not seem logically necessary. So when they generalize this behavior to math questions it's not because they can't reason but because this is the expected behavior we trained them to follow.

When a human sits down to solve a math exam, they know the context. They are not asked random math questions as they are riding the bus.

I didn't try it but my conjecture is that, for example, with some prompt engineering, explaining to o1-preview that this is a math exam, probably most/all of the performance regression with adding a superfluous clause would be recovered.

entities.text:
Can humans truly reason? Or are they just sophisticated pattern matchers?

The distinction makes no sense. What reasoning is *is* sophisticated pattern matching. Even formal mathematical logic is a set of pattern matching rules.

The paper demonstrates a benchmark showing incredible advances in AI reasoning skills, and then concludes "We hypothesize that [...] LLMs are not capable of genuine logical reasoning; instead, they attempt to replicate the reasoning steps observed in their training data."

How do you define "genuine logical reasoning"? How is it different from replicating other people's reasoning steps? There is no definition in the paper.

Does being capable of genuine logical reasoning mean scoring 100% on the benchmark? ChatGPT o1-preview scores 77.4% on their hardest benchmark, Symbolic-NoOp, math problems that try to trick you with confusing extra information. So it was able to reason through most of the problems. Do humans score better than 77.4%?

The correct conclusion is "LLMs have made large advances in reasoning skills but still make mistakes".

entities.text:
Enésimo experimento que demuestra que las LLMs son malísimas razonando.

Este experimento realizado por el grupo de investigación de Apple usaron tareas de razonamiento matemático para probar a las LLMs y "descubrieron" dos cosas:

1. Si aumentas la piezas de razonamiento decrece su rendimientos.

2. Si cambias algo del problema original decrece el rendimiento.

3. Si añades información irrelevante, que parezca relevante, decrece en rendimiento.

En conclusión: Los modelos tienden a replicar los pasos de razonamiento observados en sus datos de entrenamiento en lugar de realizar un razonamiento lógico genuino.

entities.text:
Today's "AIs" are just pattern matchers, not reasoning machines.

I predict that training AGI's will be a lot more like how we teach humans. They will acquire knowledge through conjecture and criticism.

They will think critically and be able to create new knowledge, not just regurgitate an approximation to pre-existing knowledge.

I think this is closely tied to the problem of AI explainability. AI's have no way of telling us why they have chosen to answer a question in a specific way, probably because there is not actual thought process in the backend. True AGI would not have this problem.

I don't think we will magically arrive at AGI by making bigger nets with more training and more data. It will require an entirely new model of intelligence, reasoning and knowledge.
